title: Mark Foster, from Foster The People: On Lollapalooza Chile 2025, his adventures in Santiago and writing an album about "what it is to be flawed as a human"
full_article: Foster The People's lead man shared his excitement over returning to Chile for Lollapalooza 2025. And as he reminisced about the band's past visits, where he spent days off touring around Santiago with members of The Kooks and Interpol, he discussed his band's latest album. After long seven years without new LPs, 2024's "Paradise State of Mind" comes as FPT's "deepest, most complex, rhythmic record ever," influenced by Mark's own personal growth, sobriety, and deeper connection with spirituality. In 2025, Lollapalooza¬†will, once again, take place in South America. Just a couple months after early bird tickets went on sale, Chile, Argentina and Brazil have officially announced their line-ups and Mark Foster is excited. Of course the fact his band, Foster The People, will be visiting Santiago for the fourth time in its career isn‚Äôt news to him: they were the ones saying yes and keeping the secret for months in the first place, as music stars normally do when setting off shows in advance for well-awaited festivals. But he can finally share said excitement with the world. ‚ÄúOh, man. First of all, it‚Äôs good to talk to you. I can‚Äôt wait to come back to Chile,‚Äù surfaces as his immediate greeting through his side of the screen. He‚Äôs proud of their latest record,¬†Paradise State of Mind¬†‚Äì released last August, after seven years in the making. And in an industry where artists are becoming more and more accustomed to come up with new material every couple of years, it surely might have felt like a monsoon to their fanbase. But Mark reassures it‚Äôs been worth the wait, and when being asked about what to expect from their 2025 perfomance, seems eager to share their most recent material face to face with the Chilean crowd. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs taking on these new forms that the band has never really done live, which is kind of‚Ä¶ the jazz elements of it, honestly. It‚Äôs like every night it‚Äôs different. There are moments in the show where we‚Äôre just kind of energetically vibing off of each other and it creates that feeling like‚Ä¶ which is my favorite feeling ‚Äì when I watch great actors on stage or great music. When it feels like it‚Äôs about to fall apart, but then it doesn‚Äôt, you know?¬†Or just the tension of kind of right on the edge of something new. That‚Äôs kind of what we‚Äôre going for with this new live show. So it‚Äôs going to be a lot of energy on stage. You guys have the best fans. Which is what brings out the best in us.‚Äù  Wearing a white t-shirt, he‚Äôs all smiles as his Zoom camera displays a background that devoted fans will know best: his personal studio, the same that featured FTP¬†in the Live from my Den series¬†years ago. Visually, though, it‚Äôs almost as if no time has passed since then. With his back to the keys, he‚Äôs sitting in front of the same¬†Schulze Pollmann upright piano shown in the musical special. The Motel¬†sign has also stayed, with the lower section of its words almost unreadable ‚Äì yet recognizable, above his blond head. But time has, in fact, passed. And the same man who, more than a decade ago, wrote the universally acclaimed¬†dark¬†hit¬†Pumped Up Kicks in eight hours as a warning of gun violence and honestly¬†thought no one would ever hear it (‚ÄúI was a starving artist, I didn‚Äôt have an audience. I never in a million years thought that it was going to become a global phenomenon,‚Äù he said to Billboard in 2019) looks, now, at peace with the sequence of experiences that led him here. The good, the bad.. and he certainly doesn‚Äôt disown the ugly neither. Because it‚Äôs what has shaped him into someone who‚Äôs not afraid to show vulnerability to the world. A key element for whoever aspires to make a living out of songwriting. And yes, Foster The People might have been Foster & the People as first. But in a world where, sometimes, there‚Äôs little left to actual coincidences, the fact the band had to later readecuate its name because it was usually mispronnounced might not came out of the blue. The first shows they ever played were for charities. And even now,¬†Mark Foster cares about people. A lot. It‚Äôs been said parents don‚Äôt play favorites between their own children, but when it comes to artists and their pieces of work, things might turn out a little bit different. Because the 40-year-old creative has no hesitation in letting be known that, musically speaking, he reckons Paradise State of Mind as their¬† ‚Äúdeepest, most complex, rhythmic record ever made.‚Äù CNN Chile: It‚Äôs been such a long gap since Sacred Hearts Club, and even though this new album comes as a new era, it doesn‚Äôt lose the band‚Äôs spark. In the past, you‚Äôve described your favorite music to make as¬†intelligent pop and we actually keep that here.¬†Now one turns on the radio, hears a song and is able to go like, ‚ÄòYeah, this sounds like Foster The People.‚Äô How‚Äôs that done, as a producer? Building this indistintic brand and keeping it as an legacy?¬† Mark Foster: ‚ÄúOh, wow. Thank you. I think it‚Äôs really important for artists‚Ä¶ Uhm, I‚Äôll just say for me. It‚Äôs really important for me to grow in life and to take in new experiences and to really approach a record from a place of authenticity. And I try to express myself honestly with where I‚Äôm at and what I‚Äôve learned. Seven years is a long time. It‚Äôs a lot of light to let in and certainly for myself. Like, I‚Äôve changed. I‚Äôm a totally different person in a lot of ways than I was seven years ago‚Ä¶ because, first off, I got sober in 2018, which was a huge life changer. It had been something that I had been in and out of since I was 19 years old and I eventually hit a point to where I needed to fully step away from kind of everything and re-examine my life. Mentally, emotionally, espiritually. And because of that, then, I fell in love, you know? And then, that started this whole other chapter of my life ‚Äì which, in a lot of ways, got really simple. I wasn‚Äôt touring, I wasn‚Äôt in the public eye. I kind of pulled back from all of it and got really quiet‚Ä¶ And then, the pandemic hit.¬†But within that space, I started to connect with kind of a divine ‚Äì you know, what I‚Äôll call God. But everybody has a different name for what that is.  But for me, that‚Äôs like‚Ä¶ That conversation really started to shake my perspective in a different way with art and myself, and processing things that, maybe, I had been running away from. It‚Äôs so easy to run when you‚Äôre in a band and you‚Äôre on tour. Because every single night, you‚Äôre having a party in a new city, with new people. And you can turn into Peter Pan, you know? When I meet all these old rock stars from the 70s and 80s, that they never grew. They‚Äôre still living ‚Äì they still look like they‚Äôre from the 70s, they‚Äôre still partying like they‚Äôre from the 70s and I knew that that‚Äôs not what I wanted. So, coming into this record, I feel like there are, musically, a lot of deeper things. Like the jazz incorporated into this record. There are voicings in chords, they were production kind of tricks. And musically, you know, we recorded a double quartet eight strings, multiple live horns, saxophone, flugelhorn, trumpet, bari(tone) horn, flutes. It was like a musical world to kind of step into and explore. And then, lyrically‚Ä¶¬†I just tried to be as honest as I could with where I was at. Which led to, I think, a very spiritual record. It‚Äôs very much about, I think, what it is to be flawed as a human. Like, that we‚Äôre all flawed and I tried to be honest about that and be brave¬†in expressing things that I normally wouldn‚Äôt want to say out loud ‚Äì I tried to say out loud, in hopes to connect with other people that feel the same way. But then, also, the conversation with God. Which the funny thing about talking to something spiritual is that, a lot of times, you put it out there and you don‚Äôt hear anything back right away. And sometimes, you do. And sometimes, you don‚Äôt. Sometimes, you never do‚Ä¶ But you‚Äôre kind of left just the fact that you can express something. Related article:¬†The road to success of Paul Jason Klein And then you start to notice things in your life where the answer may come in a different form. You might be reading something and then a sentence will pop-out at you and you‚Äôll be like, ‚ÄòOh my God. Is that a synchronicity? Is that a coincidence? Or is that God speaking back to me and like..?‚Äô. To me, you know, we‚Äôre living in such a time of fear. Everything you open-up, you read the headlines‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs a lot of clickbait and there‚Äôs a lot of fear. And music, to me, is the reminder that the world is beautiful and that there‚Äôs wonder and it‚Äôs really simple, you know? It‚Äôs really simple. Like, we want to love and we want to be loved. And we want to connect. And so that‚Äôs what I really tried to explore with Paradise State of Mind. CNN Chile: Since you brought up this spiritual matter ‚Äì these new songs feel like a psychedelic, lucid experience. Most of them are almost like seeing colors through your ears, if that makes any sense. MF:¬†I love that. CNN Chile:¬†And then there‚Äôs this deep vulnerability shown in the lyrics. The Holy Shangri-La, for example, comes to my mind, with the verse, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to know what is real, but all of my life I tried my best not to fear. The only way to get out is if we go through it all.‚Äù That‚Äôs pure hope, and written in such a beautiful way. How do you do that? How was creative process behind it? From writing, coming up with the sounds and taking them to the studio. MF:¬†‚ÄúThank you! Usually, I try to approach everything like a child. I grew up studying music. I played multiple instruments. I studied the history of music and I‚Äôve listened to a lot of different types of music. But when I‚Äôm writing music, I tried to forget about all of that and I approach it like a four year old. So if I go over to the piano to start a song, I‚Äôll start hitting notes that may not work. I‚Äôm not worried about hitting the right notes. I just start hitting them and what that does is it ushers in a flow state. And to where the critic is nowhere to be found and I‚Äôm just reacting. Now I‚Äôm reacting to what I‚Äôm feeling. And the Divine, or whatever‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs an energy that will come in and just start kind of buzzing through me.  So it‚Äôs all from improve. And lyrics? Same way. So, once I get, like, a song going, I‚Äôll turn on a microphone and I‚Äôll just start singing. And a lot of times, words don‚Äôt come out right away. It‚Äôs just sounds. But then, a phrase will pop. It‚Äôs like meditation. The Holy Shangri-La, songs like that‚Ä¶ That stuff kind of came out and I‚Äôm almost observing it as it‚Äôs happening, so I can‚Äôt really take credit for it, you know? I‚Äôm showing up, I‚Äôm doing it, but it‚Äôs also‚Ä¶ I feel like I‚Äôm just passing something along. And I don‚Äôt know how it works. That‚Äôs the beauty of it. I have no idea. I have no idea what I‚Äôm doing.‚Äù CNN Chile: Well, it could be a sad song. But then it turns out into solid hope:¬†‚ÄúWe can go through it.‚Äù MF:¬†‚ÄúI fell long and hard before I made this record. Because, as a songwriter, there‚Äôs a lot of things that I want to do. There‚Äôs a lot of songs I want to write. I almost made a punk record before this. Before that, I was working on a 50s and 60s inspired, like Motown, Beach Boys, (The)¬†Supremes‚Äô¬†kind of styled record. So I like riding a lot of different things, right? But the intention ‚Äì I had to think long and hard of like, ‚ÄòWhat do I want to say now?‚Äô and I find, as an artist‚Ä¶ You know, it might sound lofty, or like pretentious, or like I‚Äôm being too serious about it. But to me, it is serious that there‚Äôs a responsibility that comes with being a story teller. I feel a responsibility for what I want to say next.
